code_quality.details: Excellent naming conventions with clear function and variable names. Clean separation of concerns: routes, database, utils in separate modules. Proper error handling with try/catch and next(err) propagation to global error handler. No dead code, no eval(), no hardcoded secrets. Helmet for security headers, Morgan for logging. Helper functions (toObj, toArray) properly extracted to utils/helpers.js. Swagger JSDoc annotations are thorough and well-structured.

documentation.details: Outstanding README with badges (CI, SonarCloud, Coverage, Docker, Uptime), table of contents, full API reference with request/response examples, setup instructions, env vars documentation, Docker instructions, project structure, security section, CI/CD secrets guide, and monitoring info. Swagger UI active at /api-docs with complete JSDoc annotations. .env.example present.

teams.summary: Top-tier project. Clean, well-structured code with comprehensive documentation. One of the best submissions — clear effort put into every aspect.
tips: Name your PRs with conventional commit format (feat: xxx, fix: xxx) — squash merges use the PR title as the commit message
Consider adding input validation with a library like Zod for more robust request handling
Add a .env.example file explanation in your README for env var descriptions

code_quality.details: Good structure with routes/database separation. Proper error handling with try/catch and Sentry integration. Parameterized SQL queries. However: console.log statements left in production code (e.g., 'someone hit the root endpoint', 'creating todo', 'found X todos'), use of 'var' instead of const/let in GET /todos. Helper functions (toObj, toArray) defined inline in routes file rather than extracted. Swagger uses a static JSON file rather than JSDoc generation.

documentation.details: Good README with CI/SonarCloud badges, feature list, stack description, install instructions, test commands, Swagger mention, and CI/CD pipeline description. Missing: no .env.example documentation, no API endpoint reference in README, no Docker usage instructions despite having a Dockerfile.

teams.summary: Solid project with good CI/CD setup and Sentry integration. Code has some leftover debug logs and a var usage. Documentation covers CI well but misses API reference details.
tips: Remove console.log debug statements from production code — use a proper logger or remove them entirely
Replace 'var x' with 'const' in GET /todos route
Add a .env.example file so others know which env vars are needed

code_quality.details: Strong code quality with Zod validation schemas for input validation — excellent pattern. Helmet for security, Sentry for monitoring, Winston logger instead of console.log. Good separation with helpers.js, logger.js. Parameterized queries throughout. Proper error handling. Minor issues: error.log file committed to repo (should be gitignored), some French error messages mixed with English.

documentation.details: Good README with multiple badges (Quality Gate, Coverage, Uptime, CodeQL, Trivy, Morgan). Feature list, stack, prerequisites, install instructions, Docker usage, local security testing guides. Has .env.example. Missing: no API endpoint table/reference in README (relies solely on Swagger). Swagger active at /api-docs.

teams.summary: Good project with standout Zod validation and proper logging. The error.log file in the repo is a small oversight. Documentation is decent but could use an API reference section.
tips: Add error.log to .gitignore — log files should never be committed
Add an API endpoint reference table in your README for quick reference
Standardize error messages to one language (French or English, not both)

code_quality.details: Clean code with good structure: routes, database, utils separated. Helmet for security, Sentry for monitoring. Helpers extracted to utils/helpers.js. No try/catch in route handlers (errors will propagate to Express error handler), which is a valid pattern but risky without async error wrapper. No dead code, no eval(). Proper env var usage. Swagger with JSDoc. Good routing — search endpoint placed before /:id to avoid conflicts.

documentation.details: Excellent README with many badges (Quality Gate, Codecov, CI status, Uptime). Full table of contents, detailed stack description, installation guide, env vars table, Docker instructions with GHCR pull command, endpoint table with examples, Swagger mention, comprehensive CI/CD pipeline description with secrets table. .env.example present.

teams.summary: Very strong project. Clean code with great documentation. The lack of try/catch in routes is a minor concern but the global error handler compensates. Excellent CI/CD setup with rollback workflows.
tips: Consider wrapping async route handlers in try/catch or use an async error wrapper middleware for safety
Name your PRs with conventional commit format (feat: xxx, fix: xxx) — squash merges use the PR title as the commit message
Add rate limiting middleware to protect against abuse

code_quality.details: Advanced setup with feature flags, structured logging (Pino), Sentry with detailed context. Clean productionLazyImport pattern to gate debug endpoints. K8s manifests with Kustomize overlays show infrastructure maturity. Swagger with static JSON. Good error handling. /debug endpoint exists but is properly gated behind NODE_ENV !== production. One concern: debug endpoint returns only a static message now (good), but the pattern still registers the route in non-prod.

documentation.details: Comprehensive README with badges, full API reference with request/response examples for every endpoint, Docker and docker-compose instructions, Sentry setup guide, env vars documented. Missing: no installation steps (git clone, npm install), no table of contents.

teams.summary: Impressive infrastructure work — K8s, ArgoCD, feature flags, structured logging. Code is well-organized. Documentation is thorough but missing basic setup steps.
tips: Add basic 'Getting Started' section with git clone and npm install steps
Remove or protect the /debug endpoint — even gated by NODE_ENV, it's a risk if NODE_ENV is misconfigured
Add a .env.example file so others know which env vars are needed

code_quality.details: Clean, minimal code. Good separation with app.js/server.js split. Swagger loaded from YAML file. Parameterized queries. No security middleware (no Helmet). No error handling — no try/catch anywhere in routes, no global error handler. If the database throws, the app crashes. Helpers (toObj, toArray) defined inline in routes. Prettier and ESLint configured — good tooling.

documentation.details: Good README with badges (SonarCloud, GHCR), feature list, stack, install instructions, env vars, Swagger mention, endpoint table, project structure, Docker instructions, npm scripts. Has .env.example. Missing: no API request/response examples.

teams.summary: Functional project with good tooling (Prettier, ESLint, Spectral). Main weakness is zero error handling in routes — this is a significant gap. Documentation is solid.

Add Helmet middleware for HTTP security headers

code_quality.details: Clean ES module code with good structure. Uses Vitest instead of Jest — modern choice. Scalar API reference instead of swagger-ui. /debug endpoint exists and exposes SECRET_KEY and API_KEY — gated behind NODE_ENV=development but still a security concern in the codebase. No error handler middleware. console.log statements in routes. Helpers inline in routes file. esbuild for bundling — nice touch.

documentation.details: Excellent README with CI/CD badges, full table of contents, prerequisites, setup, env vars table, running instructions, test commands, Docker with GHCR pull, complete API reference with all endpoints documented including query params, request/response bodies, and status codes.
